20.text:
I shall begin by introducing my partner who’s
not here today, Dr. Edward Town, who is currently

26.text:
working as a postdoctoral Research Fellow
on the ‘Reformation to Restoration’ project

30.text:
at the Yale Center for British Art in New
Haven. Ed worked at the gallery on the Making

35.text:
Art in Tudor Britain project, and he published
a biographical dictionary of London painters

40.text:
in the Walpole Society in 2014.
So, Rowland Lockey, the mysterious Rowland

48.text:
Lockey, was a goldsmith and picture maker.
He was born in the parish of St Bride, Fleet

53.text:
Street, in around 1566, the son of the armourer,
Leonard Lockey, he was apprentice to Nicholas

58.text:
Hilliard for eight years, starting on 29 September
1581, and was made free before 1592. He was

66.text:
commended for ‘oil and limning, in some
measure’, by Richard Haydock in the preface

70.text:
to his translation of Lomazzo in 1598. And
he was included in a list of artists who were

74.text:
proficient in the use of dry colours in Edward
Norgate’s Miniatura.

78.text:
But the National Portrait Gallery’s portrait
of Thomas More’s family and descendants,

83.text:
a late-16th century copy, an update of Holbein’s
famous portrait, was commissioned by Thomas

88.text:
More the Younger. And the attribution derives
from the fact that the painting was seen in

93.text:
Lockey’s studio by the antiquary, William
Burton, who said and I quote, ‘Rowland Lockey,

98.text:
one whom I knew very well when he lived in
Fleet Street, who was both skilful in limning

102.text:
and in oil-works and perspectives; at whose
house I once saw a neat piece in oil, containing

107.text:
in one table the picture of Sir John More,
a judge of the King's Bench in the time of

111.text:
Henry VIII, and of his wife; and of Sir Thomas
More, Lord Chancellor, his son and wife; and

115.text:
of all the lineal heirs male descended from
them; together with each man’s wife, until

120.text:
that present year living.’
So, this portrait provides a fascinating means

127.text:
to discuss the copies after Holbein’s portrait
that were being produced in the late-16th

131.text:
century, in the context of contemporary portraiture.
We analysed a number of copies after Holbein

136.text:
as part of the Making Art in Tudor Britain
project, and found that they were the product

140.text:
of different studios. We haven’t examined
the More family portrait in detail, but in

144.text:
the future, it’d be interesting to consider
in relationship to these other portraits after

148.text:
Holbein, and then in relation to other works
by Lockey, as and when attributions may appear.

154.text:
But to have, ostensibly, the work of both
styles within one painting provides incredibly

158.text:
useful reference point, particularly considering
Lockey’s work as a copyist.

165.text:
The portrait also provides a fascinating glimpse,
you may have missed her, in the upper right

170.text:
corner, of another area of Lockey’s portraiture;
the production of copies after portraits by

175.text:
lesser-known artists. So, Anne Cresacre—just
to go back so there she is on the wall behind—is

185.text:
depicted both in the copy of the original
Holbein and in this portrait on the wall,

189.text:
so we have, kind of, three styles of portraits
occurring within this one image. Other works

195.text:
that have been associated with Lockey are
the two portraits inscribed ‘Rolandus Lockey’,

203.text:
the version of the More family portrait at
Nostell Priory, and the portrait of Margaret

208.text:
Beaufort at St John's College, Cambridge.
The inscription in the Nostell Priory painting

213.text:
is a later addition, and the stylistic similarity
in relationship to the Gallery version has

218.text:
been questioned and discussed by David [Taylor]
and by Jane Eade in an article in Apollo.

222.text:
I can wave it around if anybody is interested.
But it’s interesting that the name uses

228.text:
the Latinised form in both the Lockey and
the… Margaret Beaufort and the Nostell Priory

233.text:
portraits—this is, kind of, the common thread
to the inscription that’s interesting. And

237.text:
it’s also the miniature of the More family
portrait in the V&A, which was first linked

241.text:
to Lockey by Roy Strong, on the grounds that
he was renowned as a limner. So, you have

244.text:
this large scale version, the small scale
version, he is the one person who may have

249.text:
been capable of doing both.
But that said, given Lockey’s reputation

252.text:
at the time, it seems remarkable that there
aren’t more paintings attributed to him.

256.text:
As I said, he was trained by Hilliard, and
the documentary evidence suggests that he

260.text:
was successfully working as an artist at a
time when court portraiture was dominated

264.text:
by Marcus Gheeraerts the Younger and John
de Critz the Elder—and he seems to be, kind

268.text:
of, holding his own very well. Another kind
of glimpse of Lockey can perhaps be seen in

275.text:
the work of the artists he trained in the
years after he became free in 1592, and these

280.text:
included Richard Greenbury, his brother, Nicholas
Lockey, to whom he left all his Italian prints

284.text:
in his will, John Langton and Ralph Blackmore.
And Ed’s written more about these individuals

289.text:
in the biographical dictionary.
But I just want to bring up these paintings

293.text:
again to think of the, kind of, lineage that
Lockey was connected into. In the payments…

301.text:
It’s in the payments in relation to Hardwick
Hall and the Talbot and Cavendish families

305.text:
that Lockey leaves, perhaps, his more significant
traces in the archival record. And it therefore

309.text:
seems most likely that it’s in this picture
collection, as was now disseminated into,

314.text:
sort of, various places, that further examples
of Lockey’s work are to be found.

320.text:
On 24 July 1592, two payments totalling £3
were made by Elizabeth, Countess of Shrewsbury,

327.text:
to Hilliard for ‘drawing of one picture’,
while the following payment in her accounts

332.text:
of 40 shillings was made to Rowland for the
drawing of one other. And these are, kind

335.text:
of, small sums of money that don’t suggest,
kind of, large scale works. In August 1609,

342.text:
Bess’s son, William Cavendish, paid £3,
6 shillings, 8 pence for ‘making the pictures’;

348.text:
40 shillings for ‘12 ells of canvas, for
pictures’, at 3 shillings 4 pence the ell;

353.text:
and £10 in part payment of a bill for drawing
15 pictures.

358.text:
In October, Lockey was paid £15 in full for
drawing 16 pictures, that had been paid to

363.text:
him in London, and another payment in the
country. And in September, there were payments

368.text:
to porters that bought pictures from Mr. Lockey.
And Lockey himself was paid £8 for ‘Mr.

373.text:
Cavendish’s picture’, ‘My Lady’s Grace’
and ‘My Lordship’s First Wife’, for

377.text:
‘canvas and gilding all the frames of the
pictures’ made at Hardwick according to

380.text:
his bill.
And also, to, kind of, contextualise the types

384.text:
of works that we’re looking for. We have
not only the, kind of, More family portrait

388.text:
for reference, but also the fact that the
Talbots were discerning patrons. And a letter

395.text:
from John Talbot of Grafton to his cousin,
George Talbot, Earl of Shrewsbury, in… On

401.text:
7 July 1597, provides one of the few, sort
of, descriptive references of the appreciation

405.text:
of a portrait that had been presented as a
gift from this period. And he wrote, ‘I

410.text:
most humbly thank you for the picture that
you have sent unto to me, amongst many other

414.text:
infinite favours. Surely, he had been much
beholden to the painting… to the painter

419.text:
for gracing him with long tuffs in his neck
and curling of his hair. Before of the best

423.text:
art-like fashion, he lack of nothing but a
great pair of ruffs.’

429.text:
So, to some of the Hardwick paintings that
have been associated with Lockey at various

434.text:
points, but none of which are straightforward.
And so, David has been talking about Mary,

438.text:
Queen of Scots, and Catharine can talk about
James. But just to… He’s been known to

443.text:
be associated with Hardwick, but it’s difficult
to pin down exactly which things he was doing.

448.text:
So, for Mary, Queen of Scots, Lockey was evidently
involved in the production of portraits of

454.text:
Mary, Queen of Scots. And this is entirely
appropriate. Because, as David showed, the

460.text:
portrait type, the likeness of the queen is
associated with a miniature by Nicholas Hilliard.

464.text:
And so it’s very plausible that Lockey,
his pupil, would’ve had access to her likeness

469.text:
to be able to create portraits of the queen
that were, kind of, particularly in demand

473.text:
after James’s accession.
And there are payments in January 1610 to

479.text:
‘Mr. Lockey’s man’ for ‘going with
the Queen of Scots’ picture to My Lord Arundel’s’,

483.text:
and two porters to carry it. Then, on the
21 June 1613, 2 shillings was paid to Lockey’s

489.text:
men, who brought ‘the Scot’s queen’s
picture’, and £9 was given for the picture

495.text:
itself. But this portrait is difficult to
track down, because it was presented to the

498.text:
Lord Privy Seal, Henry Howard, 1st Earl of
Northampton, who, in his entry, had at least

502.text:
four portraits of Mary, so it, kind of, went
into this collection of portraits of Mary.

507.text:
Similarly, another area that’s, kind of,
a little more difficult to unpick, the portraits

515.text:
that Catharine’s going to talk about more,
but these have been both associated with Lockey

519.text:
at, kind of, various points in a, sort of,
like, oh, they’re largely on canvas and

527.text:
should be Lockey, but it all gets a bit more
complicated. So, Ed and I decided instead

530.text:
to consider the works that were listed in
the payments to Lockey, looking for images

535.text:
of Sir William Cavendish in the Heinz Archive.
So, this portrait at Welbeck shows the sitter

544.text:
in dress of 1609, so it’s the date at which
the portraits were commissioned from Lockey,

550.text:
you had the very handy, kind of, cross reference,
in terms of dress to the portraits of James

553.text:
I by John de Critz.
And it doesn’t… This is obviously working

558.text:
from black and white photograph. I have not
seen the painting, so, you know, at that layer

561.text:
of interpretation. It is… They’re not,
kind of, completely, yes, completely disparate

567.text:
items. They are, plausibly, things that could
sit in the same world. So, this is the detailed

571.text:
portrait from the family of Thomas More the
Younger. And Ed very kindly put together this

579.text:
very complicated family tree of the, yes,
Cavendish childhood links, but it does end

586.text:
up, as you can see at the bottom, Duke of
Portland at Welbeck. So there’s very plausible

592.text:
reasons why a portrait of Cavendish could
end up at Welbeck at a later point. But, you

598.text:
know, very much more to be done, considering
that portrait.

602.text:
There’s also a payment in December 1612
for a portrait of Sir William Maynard, who

609.text:
married William Cavendish’s daughter, Frances.
In the Heinz Archive, we have only one image

614.text:
of William Maynard. But again, very interestingly,
it is of a portrait of exactly the right date,

620.text:
sort of, 1612. Nice comparative there with
the Richard Sackville, 3rd Earl of Dorset,

624.text:
in terms of, kind of, ruff-shape. So it’s
a, plausibly, portrait of the right date,

629.text:
presuming that it is the right sitter, sold
at Sotheby’s in ‘74. And again, not…

635.text:
You know, working from a black and white photo,
a very damaged painting. But nonetheless,

643.text:
you could see how it would be worth investing
further, to see if there is a relationship

647.text:
to the portraits. This time, with the young
Cresacre More in the More family portrait.

657.text:
In relation to the 1609 portrait of ‘My
Lordship’s First Wife’, it’s perhaps

662.text:
interesting to consider the portrait that
was identified as possibly Anne Keighley.

667.text:
And even though this identifies… Identification
of the sitter as Anne Keighley, is in relation

671.text:
to a portrait that’s in the 1601 inventory,
so the two bits of information can’t match

676.text:
up. But it’s intriguing that she married
Cavendish in March 1581, and had clearly died

680.text:
by 1609, because the payment to Lockey is
for the portrait of your first wife, and the

687.text:
current lady’s grace.
So, Lockey’s portrait that he produced in

690.text:
1609 would’ve had to be a copy of a portrait
that was likely produced between 1581 and

697.text:
1609. And this portrait is of, kind of, particular
interest—Ed and I, kind of, flagged it up—because

703.text:
it is on canvas, unlike the other works from
the collection from the 1590s, such as the

709.text:
Mary Cavendish. So this is of, kind of, the
bits of information that you can link together.

715.text:
So, while the research undertaken as part
of Making Art in Tudor Britain has shown the

719.text:
default assumption that paintings on canvas
date from the 17th century is not, kind of,

724.text:
correct, the fact that there are payments
made for… to Lockey for canvas, for painting,

729.text:
means a crucial factor to take into consideration
when assessing which works by him may survive

735.text:
within the collection.
So, as a, kind of, 1590s portrait of a woman

741.text:
that’s on canvas, I think, interesting to
consider. It also brings into consideration

749.text:
this portrait of an unknown man, which is
very compositionally similar to works by Robert

754.text:
Peake the Elder, shows a sitter from the 1590s.
So, is this another copy commissioned by Cavendish?

760.text:
And the thing with Lockey to, kind of, have
to unpick is, how do you discern an artist

764.text:
hand when you’re working from copies? You
know, kind of, what are you assessing?

770.text:
But the payment for nine ells of canvas means
it’d be fascinating to use this group of

774.text:
portraits as a case study for the comparative
analysis of canvas weave from X-rays, which

779.text:
has proved successful at linking canvas supports
from paintings to similar bolts of cloth.

785.text:
So, using the X-rays to then have, kind of,
yes, the data analysis to see if there are

790.text:
any canvas links across the group.
And finally, I just wanted to conclude. With…

798.text:
If you’re using the More… The other portraits
in the More family as a, kind of, point of

804.text:
reference as to what Lockey’s wider oeuvre
may have been, it opens up the idea of assessing

809.text:
portraits in other collections. Ed has been
looking closely at the work the group, identified

814.text:
by Strong as ‘unknown follower of Gheeraerts’
in The English Icon, and bringing, kind of,

818.text:
other paintings into consideration. And among
these is this portrait of an unknown man from

823.text:
the collection in Bolton, which again, does
seem to sit in a plausible way with the Thomas

829.text:
More the Younger from the large scale family
portrait.

836.text:
And this...So, yes, so the research for this
is very much in the, kind of, early stages

842.text:
of opening up consideration. The group is
quite large. And one of the things that it,

847.text:
kind of, shares, that… Is this slightly
uncomfortable disjunction between the, sort

851.text:
of, skill in the execution of the faces, and
the slightly uncomfortable proportions of

855.text:
the figures and placement of the figures.
And as a, kind of, final question to you all,

860.text:
is whether this could be an interesting, kind
of, legacy of the training that Lockey would’ve

863.text:
received from Nicholas Hilliard as a miniature
painter?
